questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of varenicline? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Partial agonist at acetylcholine receptors

 

Explanation:

 

Varenicline acts as a partial agonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, specifically the α4β2 subtype. It binds to these receptors and produces a weaker effect than nicotine while simultaneously blocking nicotine from binding, thereby reducing the reward associated with smoking. This dual action helps decrease craving for nicotine and makes varenicline the most effective anti-smoking medication available.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Antagonist at serotonergic receptors: Varenicline does not act on serotonergic receptors. This mechanism is associated with certain antidepressants and anxiolytics.
  • Option B. Blocks dopamine receptors: Dopamine receptor blockade is the mechanism of action for antipsychotic drugs, not varenicline. While smoking does increase dopamine release, varenicline works directly on nicotinic receptors.
  • Option C. Inverse agonist at acetylcholine receptors: Varenicline is not an inverse agonist. Inverse agonists produce effects opposite to agonists by reducing receptor activity below baseline. Varenicline partially activates the receptor while blocking full activation by nicotine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is the most effective anti-smoking drug, working through partial agonism at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors to reduce craving while simultaneously blocking the rewarding effects of nicotine from cigarettes.

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true about Barrett esophagus except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

 

Not squamous cell carcinoma, but esophageal adenocarcinoma is the cancer risk that is increased by Barrett's esophagus.

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition.

 

Barrett's epithelium (columnar metaplasia), dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, and esophageal adenocarcinoma develop sequentially from one another.

 

Microscopically, goblet cells are shown to have taken the place of the squamous esophageal epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complication of chronic GERD: True, as Barrett’s esophagus commonly develops as a response to the damage from chronic acid reflux.

 

Option B. Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD: True, as approximately 10% of GERD patients develop Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. Intestinal metaplasia: True, and is a defining characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous cells to columnar cells, not squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Mitochondrial matrix enzyme is? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Citrate synthase

 

Citrate synthase is an enzyme located in the mitochondrial matrix, where it catalyzes the first step of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle. This step involves the condensation of oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to form citrate. The TCA cycle is a central metabolic pathway that plays a critical role in cellular respiration, generating energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

 

 

Note – all the enzymes of TCA are in mitochondrial matrix except – Succinate dehydrogenase (present in inner mitochondrial membrane)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monoamine oxidase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It is located on the outer mitochondrial membrane, not in the mitochondrial matrix.

 

Option C. ATP synthase: This enzyme complex is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is responsible for synthesizing ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate during oxidative phosphorylation. It is part of the electron transport chain (ETC) as Complex V.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is predominantly found in peroxisomes, not in the mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate synthase is a key enzyme of the TCA cycle located in the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

Asherman Syndrome

 

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility

 

Diagnosis –

 

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

 

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

 

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal ligation: Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Endocervical polyp: In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

choices.text: The second intercostal space on the right side
The second intercostal space on the left side
The third intercostal space on the right side
The third intercostal space on the left side

questions.text: In the context of cardiac examination, Erb's point corresponds to which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. The third intercostal space on the left side.

 

Explanation:

 

Erb's point is anatomically located at the third intercostal space on the left side of the sternum. This is an important auscultatory area during cardiac examination as multiple murmurs may be heard at this location. The third left intercostal space is a significant area where sounds from different cardiac structures converge, making it a crucial point for clinical examination of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The second intercostal space on the right side: This is the aortic area of cardiac auscultation where aortic valve sounds and murmurs related to the aortic valve are best heard. It is not Erb's point.

 

Option B. The second intercostal space on the left side: This is the pulmonic area where pulmonic valve sounds and murmurs associated with the pulmonary valve are best heard. This is not Erb's point.

 

Option C. The third intercostal space on the right side: This is not a standard auscultatory area for cardiac examination. Erb's point is specifically on the left side, not the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erb's point is located at the third intercostal space on the left side of the sternum and serves as an important auscultatory area where multiple cardiac murmurs may be detected during examination.

questions.text: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of breast cancer. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of which nucleotide? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TMP

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). This enzyme is critical in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, a precursor needed for the de novo synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to a decrease in thymine monophosphate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis and repair. This inhibition ultimately impedes the proliferation of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, making methotrexate effective in the treatment of breast cancer and other malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate is not directly affected by methotrexate. Methotrexate does not inhibit the synthesis of purine nucleotides like AMP.

 

Option B. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide, but its synthesis is not directly impacted by methotrexate.

 

Option C. UMP: Uridine monophosphate is another pyrimidine nucleotide that is not directly influenced by methotrexate's mechanism of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to a reduction in thymine monophosphate (TMP) synthesis, which is critical for DNA synthesis. This makes it effective in the treatment of cancers, including breast cancer

questions.text: Excess ammonia reduces which of the following substrates of the Krebs cycle?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha ketoglutarate

 

Excess ammonia has been shown to inhibit alpha-ketoglutarate. Ammonia interferes with the normal functioning of the Krebs cycle by inhibiting key enzymes, including those involved in the conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate. This disruption in the Krebs cycle can lead to metabolic imbalances and other health issues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce malate. Malate is a key intermediate in the Krebs cycle but is not typically affected by ammonia levels.

 

Option B. Oxaloacetate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce oxaloacetate either. Oxaloacetate is another intermediate in the Krebs cycle and is not a primary target of ammonia toxicity.

 

Option C. Fumarate: Similar to malate and oxaloacetate, fumarate is not a direct target of excess ammonia. It plays a role in the Krebs cycle but is not significantly affected by ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the CNS, Alpha ketoglutarate can combine with excess ammonia forming glutamate to reduce ammonia levels.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by which dermatome ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T10

 

The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

 

The T10 dermatome is significant because it corresponds to the umbilical region. Often, when clinicians check for sensation around the umbilicus, they are assessing the integrity of the T10 spinal nerve. This dermatome covers the region around the umbilicus, extending a bit below it.

 

Dermatomes are specific areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerves originating from a single spinal nerve root. Each segment of the spinal cord gives rise to a pair (left and right) of spinal nerves, and each of these spinal nerves carries sensory information from a distinct region of the body to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8: The T8 dermatome primarily covers the area just above the level of the umbilicus. If you were to draw a horizontal line around the trunk at the level of the umbilicus, this would approximate the center of the T8 dermatomal distribution.

 

Option B. T9: The T9 dermatome is situated just below the T8 level and above T10. It covers the region between the umbilicus and the midline of the abdomen, approximately at the level where the xiphoid process (the small cartilaginous extension at the lower end of the sternum) ends.

 

Option D. T11: The T11 dermatome covers an area of the anterior trunk below the T10 level but above the groin. It is positioned just before the first lumbar dermatome starts, and it sits above the inguinal ligament, which is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows:

questions.text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is distinguished by which of the following histological features? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Linear grooves in the nuclei

 

Explanation: 

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterized by proliferation of Langerhans cells, which have a distinctive nuclear morphology featuring linear grooves. These nuclear grooves are often described as having a "coffee bean" appearance and represent a key diagnostic feature of LCH. S-100 is a positive marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis, which is listed alongside melanoma and schwannoma (referenced as "MaSaLa"). The disease is also notable for its association with BRAF V600E mutations, which can be targeted with BRAF inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S-100 negativity - This is incorrect because Langerhans cell histiocytosis is actually S-100 positive. S-100 is a marker for "Melanoma, Schwannoma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis (MaSaLa)."

 

Option B. CD-21 positivity - This is incorrect. CD21 is not a marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis. CD21 is actually a receptor used by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) to infect B cells.

 

Option C. Basophilic Cytoplasm - This feature is not characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The distinctive morphologic feature of LCH cells is their nuclear appearance, not cytoplasmic staining properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is characterized by cells with distinctive nuclear grooves and positivity for S-100; it has been found to frequently harbor BRAF V600E mutations, making it potentially responsive to targeted therapy with BRAF inhibitors.

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mite

 

Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The primary vector for this disease is not the adult mite but its larval form, known as a chigger. Chiggers are tiny, red larval mites that transmit the bacteria to humans through their bite. The disease is also sometimes referred to as "chigger-borne rickettsiosis" due to this vector relationship.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tick: While ticks are vectors for other rickettsial diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever (caused by Rickettsia rickettsii) and Indian tick typhus (caused by Rickettsia conorii), they are not responsible for transmitting scrub typhus.

 

 

Option B. Louse: Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. They do not transmit scrub typhus.

 

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for endemic typhus caused by Rickettsia typhi. They are not associated with scrub typhus transmission.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickettsial diseases:

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caspase – 1

 

Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.

 

Pyroptosis is a type of controlled cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis that is mediated by IL-1. It takes part in the removal of microbially and necrotically affected cells.

 

Caspase-1 and the inflammasome complex are both activated.

 

  • IL-1 production causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Caspase - 3, C. Caspase - 9 and  D. Caspase – 8: These caspases are primarily involved in the apoptosis pathway, not in the activation of IL-1. Caspase-3 and caspase-9 are part of the apoptotic cascade that leads to programmed cell death without inflammation. Caspase-8 is involved in extrinsic apoptosis signaling and can overlap with inflammatory pathways but does not directly activate IL-1.

 

Educational objective:

 

Caspase-1 is critical for the activation of IL-1, directly linking it to the inflammatory response and distinguishing it from other caspases primarily involved in apoptotic pathways. This mechanism underscores the specific role of the inflammasome and pyroptosis in immune defense and inflammatory regulation.

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: What is the dose of corticosteroids for lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

Corticosteroids are administered to pregnant women who are at risk of preterm delivery (before 34 weeks of gestation) to enhance fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The correct dosing regimen for corticosteroids is crucial for their effectiveness.

 

Dexamethasone and Betamethasone are the two corticosteroids commonly used for this purpose:

 

  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours, totaling four doses. This regimen ensures adequate fetal lung maturation by delivering consistent steroid levels over 48 hours.
  • Betamethasone is typically administered as 12 mg intramuscularly, given in two doses 24 hours apart. This regimen also effectively promotes fetal lung maturity but involves fewer doses compared to Dexamethasone.

 

In this specific case, the correct answer is Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses because it follows the standard protocol for promoting lung maturity in fetuses at risk of preterm birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fetal lung maturity, the standard dosing regimen of Dexamethasone is 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses. This regimen is effective in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.

questions.text: Which injury is not a part of ‘terrible triad of elbow’? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture of olecranon

 

TERRIBLE TRIAD OF ELBOW

 

  • A notoriously unstable injury is the elbow dislocation with associated fractures of the radial head and coronoid process of the ulna is termed the terrible triad of the elbow.
  • Elbow dislocation is often associated with posterolateral dislocation or LCL injury.
  • Mechanism of injury is fall on supinated forearm and extended arm that results in a combination of valgus, axial, and posterolateral rotatory forces.
  • This produces posterolateral dislocation.
  • Structures of elbow fail from lateral to medial:  
    • LCL
    • Anterior capsule
    • Possible MCL disruption
  • Patients complain of pain, clicking and locking with elbow in extension.
  • Physical examination shows possible varus / valgus instability patterns.
  • Radiographs help evaluate the concentricity of humeroulnar and radiocapitellar joints; specifically, lateral films can assist in diagnosing coronoid fractures.

 

 

  • CT scan is routinely obtained to identify fracture patterns, comminution, and displacement, which may not be evident on plain radiographs. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fracture of olecranon is not a part of the terrible triad injury of the elbow.
  • In the terrible triad injury, the radial head and coronoid process are fractured, along with dislocation of the elbow joint.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with sudden severe headache. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage)

 

The CT scan shows hyperdensity (bright white areas) within the CSF cisterns, indicating the presence of blood. This presentation is typical of a Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH), which is often caused by a ruptured aneurysm, particularly in the circle of Willis, as confirmed by the accompanying CT angiography. The sudden severe headache experienced by the patient, often described as a "thunderclap headache," is characteristic of SAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SDH (Subdural Hemorrhage): SDH typically appears as a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid membrane. It is not confined to the CSF cisterns and does not present with the sudden onset severe headache seen in SAH.

 

Option C. EDH (Epidural Hemorrhage): EDH is characterized by a biconvex, lens-shaped appearance on imaging. It is usually associated with trauma and does not involve the subarachnoid space or present with CSF cistern hyperdensity.

 

Option D. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, often due to trauma or surgical procedures. It shows air density areas on imaging, which appear black, unlike the hyperdense (white) blood seen in SAH. The classic sign associated with pneumocephalus is the Mount Fuji sign, which is not seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAH presents with sudden, severe headache and is identified on CT by hyperdensity in the CSF cisterns. The most common cause is aneurysmal rupture, best evaluated using CT angiography.

questions.text: Catecholamine secretion is increased by all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine) are released from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve terminals in response to various physiological stressors. Their secretion is typically increased during situations that trigger the "fight or flight" response.

 

Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine release because high blood glucose levels don't represent a threat to the body that requires mobilization of energy resources. Catecholamines work to increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Once glucose levels are already elevated, there's no physiological need for additional catecholamine release.

 

Catecholamine release occurs during hypoglycemia, quiet standing, surgery, smoking, exercise, and is highest in conditions like pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, and ketoacidosis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglycemia: Incorrect. Hypoglycemia is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release. When blood glucose levels fall below normal, catecholamines are released to mobilize glucose stores and increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. This is an essential protective mechanism to ensure adequate glucose supply to the brain and other vital organs during periods of low blood glucose.

 

Option C. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking causes nicotine to enter the bloodstream, which stimulates the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines. The nicotine in cigarettes acts on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia, triggering the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. This is part of the physiological response that leads to increased heart rate and blood pressure observed in smokers.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is a significant stimulus for catecholamine release. During physical activity, there's an increased demand for energy and oxygen delivery to working muscles. The sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. These catecholamines help in increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate, and they mobilize energy sources to support the increased metabolic demands of exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catecholamine secretion increases during stress conditions like hypoglycemia, smoking, and exercise, but not during hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress. Chest X ray reveals air bubbles in the left hemithorax. What is your best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a condition where there is an opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal contents to move into the chest cavity. This can lead to compression of the lungs and associated respiratory distress. The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH, as the abdominal organs such as the stomach and intestines herniate into the thoracic cavity, causing air-filled loops to appear in the hemithorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital sequestration of lung: Congenital pulmonary sequestration is a rare condition where a portion of lung tissue develops separately from the normal lung tissue and lacks a connection to the bronchial tree. It typically presents with a solid mass or cystic lesion rather than air bubbles. The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is not consistent with this condition.

 

Option C. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM): CCAM is a developmental lung abnormality characterized by the formation of cysts or masses of abnormal lung tissue. While it can lead to respiratory distress in newborns, it usually presents as a cystic or solid mass rather than air bubbles in the chest X-ray.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the best possible diagnosis given the described findings of air bubbles in the left hemithorax and respiratory distress in the newborn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH

questions.text: In a prolonged intubation patient, the following is seen. Staging for this is given by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotton Meyer

 

The images depict subglottic stenosis, which is a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, often due to prolonged intubation. This condition results from the high-pressure cuff of the endotracheal tube irritating the mucosa beneath the glottis. The Cotton Meyer classification system is used to stage subglottic stenosis based on the degree of airway narrowing:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radkowski: This staging system is used for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), not subglottic stenosis.

 

Option C. AJCC: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to subglottic stenosis.

 

Option D. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for categorizing the extent of cancers, specifically focusing on tumor size (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M). It is not relevant for subglottic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Subglottic stenosis resulting from prolonged intubation is staged using the Cotton Meyer classification, which grades the severity based on the percentage of airway narrowing

 

  • Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battle sign

 

The image shows Battle's sign.

 

It is retroarticular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

 

Option D: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?(NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrophobia

 

This is the fear of heights.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarophobia: This is the fear of itching or of the insects that cause itching.

 

Option B. Algophobia: This is the fear of pain.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of open spaces or of being in crowded, public places like markets, or the fear of leaving a safe place, often associated with panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

 

To assess preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, the recommended area to place the pulse oximeter is the right upper limb. The right upper limb is preductal, meaning it receives blood directly from the aorta before it passes through the ductus arteriosus. This positioning is crucial for detecting any discrepancies between preductal and postductal oxygen saturation levels such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

If the preductal oxygen saturation is more than 5% higher than the postductal saturation (measured at the foot), it suggests the presence of a right-to-left shunt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal left upper limb: Although the left upper limb can be used, the right upper limb is preferred for preductal saturation measurement to ensure accuracy in detecting shunts.

 

Option B. Fetal left lower limb: The left lower limb is postductal, making it unsuitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Option D. Fetal right lower limb: The right lower limb is also postductal and not suitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To measure preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, place the pulse oximeter on the right upper limb. This helps in detecting any right-to-left shunt, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

questions.text: Which region of the liver is most vulnerable to ischemic injury? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Centrilobular

 

Explanation: 

 

The centrilobular region (Zone 3) is most vulnerable to ischemic injury because it is located farthest from the blood supply. Blood flows from portal tracts (containing branches of portal vein and hepatic artery) toward the central vein, creating an oxygen gradient. Hepatocytes in the centrilobular region receive blood that has already passed through other zones, making them most susceptible to hypoxia during compromised circulation. Left-sided cardiac failure or shock may lead to hepatic hypoperfusion and hypoxia, causing ischemic coagulative necrosis of hepatocytes in the central region of the lobule (centrilobular necrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periportal - The periportal region (Zone 1) is closest to the incoming blood supply from both portal vein and hepatic artery branches. It receives blood with the highest oxygen concentration, making it most resistant to ischemic injury.

 

Option B. Midzonal - The midzonal region (Zone 2) lies between periportal and centrilobular areas. It has intermediate vulnerability to ischemic injury, becoming affected after the centrilobular region but before the periportal region.

 

Option D. Perihepatic - This is not a standard term in liver lobular architecture. The liver lobule is divided into centrilobular, midzonal, and periportal regions based on proximity to central veins and portal tracts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The centrilobular region is most vulnerable to ischemic injury due to its location farthest from the blood supply, making it the first area to suffer during hypoxic conditions like cardiac failure or shock.

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a therapy that inhibits the synthesis of uric acid. His symptoms were relieved after therapy. Identify the drug he was prescribed? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allopurinol

 

Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme. It decreases the production of uric acid, therefore useful in cases of hyperuricemia and chronic gout.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acids. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation.

 

Option B. Colchicine: Colchicine is Inhibit granulocyte migration and the release of glycoprotein from neutrophils. Used in Gout, Cirrhosis, Acute Mediterranean Fever, Sarcoidosis.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a Non-Selective COX inhibitor having analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory property. A/E – Peptic ulcer disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allopurinol is the drug of choice for reducing uric acid synthesis in patients with chronic gout by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme. It effectively lowers serum and urinary uric acid levels, thereby preventing gout attacks.

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Miliary tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The given chest X-ray depicts miliary tuberculosis.

 

Miliary tuberculosis:

 

  • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT.
  • Hematogenous spread.

 

Miliary pattern D/D:   

 

  • Healed varicella
  • TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome
  • Hemosiderosis
  • Silicosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: Typically presents with bilateral opacities, predominantly in the perihilar regions, and may show Kerley B lines, none of which are visible in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Necrobiotic nodules: Commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, presenting as larger, well-defined nodules, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Tuberculoma: Typically appears as a solitary, well-defined round lesion, often with a calcified center, not the diffuse pattern observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Hepatic artery

 

The image shows the blood supply of the gallbladder region. The arrow pointed towards  the Right Hepatic artery. It’s a branch of the Proper Hepatic artery and supplies the right lobe of the liver. The Right Hepatic artery gives off the Cystic artery which supplies the gallbladder. It is important because:

 

  • It is one of the components of Calot's triangle
  • Landmark for surgical procedures like cholecystectomy
  • It has a relatively constant anatomical position in relation to the bile duct and portal vein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Hepatic artery: Incorrect because Left Hepatic artery supplies the left lobe of liver.It does not have a direct relationship with gallbladder and it Would be located on the other side of the proper hepatic artery bifurcation

 

Option C. Common Hepatic artery: Incorrect because Common Hepatic artery is a branch of celiac trunk.It divides into Proper Hepatic artery and Gastroduodenal artery

 

Option D. Cystic artery: Incorrect because Cystic artery is a branch of Right Hepatic artery. It directly supplies the gallbladder

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Right Hepatic artery is a branch of the proper hepatic artery that supplies the right lobe of the liver. It is an important anatomical structure in hepatobiliary surgery, as it gives rise to the cystic artery within Calot's triangle.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of non-ionizing radiation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D (Infrared Rays)

 

Explanation: 

 

Infrared rays are classified as non-ionizing radiation. Non-ionizing radiation has lower energy levels that are insufficient to remove electrons from atoms or molecules, thus not creating ions. Ultrasonography is another example of non-ionizing radiation, which is why it's often preferred for certain applications like pregnancy imaging where radiation safety is paramount.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cosmic Rays - These are high-energy particles that originate from space and are a form of ionizing radiation. They have sufficient energy to remove electrons from atoms, creating ions.

 

Option B. Gamma Rays - These are electromagnetic waves with very high frequencies and energy levels. They are definitively ionizing radiation, capable of penetrating deeply into materials and causing significant ionization.

 

Option C. X-Rays - X-rays are a form of ionizing radiation used in radiography, fluoroscopy, and CT scanning. Their ionizing properties allow them to create images by differential absorption in tissues but also necessitate radiation safety protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding which radiological techniques use ionizing versus non-ionizing radiation is crucial for making appropriate imaging choices that balance diagnostic value with patient safety considerations.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of the device shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trophoblastic disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a copper-containing IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device).
  • ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device are:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis/ Puerperal sepsis/ Current Pelvic inflammatory/ disease, Genital Tuberculosis
    • Cancers: Endometrial cancer, Cervical cancer, Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity, Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Menstruation: Intra-uterine device can be inserted even during periods although preferably it should be inserted post-menstrual

 

Option C. Immediately after delivery: This is called as Post placental IUCD insertion (within 10 mins of placental delivery)

 

Option D. Ruptured condom during intercourse: Following a ruptured condom, CUT can be inserted as an emergency contraception

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophoblastic disease is an ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549158

questions.text: Identify the histological structure shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pancreatic islet cells

 

  • The pancreas has two main parts: the exocrine and endocrine pancreas.
  • The endocrine part of the pancreas is composed of islets of Langerhans, which are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and numerous fenestrated capillaries.
  • Each islet is surrounded by a delicate capsule and appears paler than the surrounding exocrine cells due to the presence of less rough endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The image provided depicts the histology of the pancreas.

 

 

Pancreatic Islet Cells (Islets of Langerhans): Scattered throughout the pancreas, these islets are endocrine clusters differing from the surrounding exocrine pancreatic tissue.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Alpha Cells: Produce glucagon which increases blood glucose levels.
  • Beta Cells: The most common islet cell, producing insulin which decreases blood glucose levels.
  • Delta Cells: Produce somatostatin, which regulates the other islet cells.
  • Gamma Cells (PP or F cells): Produce pancreatic polypeptide, which regulates some of the pancreatic exocrine and endocrine functions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures found throughout the lymphatic system.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: A dense connective tissue covering.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule that divide the node into compartments.
  • Cortex: Contains densely packed lymphocytes and has follicles with germinal centers.
  • Medulla: Central part containing medullary cords (lymphatic tissue) and medullary sinuses filled with lymph.
  • Hilum: The area where blood vessels and nerves enter and exit and where the efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node.

 

Option B. Glomerulus: A tuft of capillaries situated within Bowman's capsule in the nephron of the kidney.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Endothelial Cells: These line the inner surface of the capillaries.
  • Basement Membrane: Lies between the endothelial cells and the podocytes, playing a critical role in filtering the blood.
  • Podocytes: These are specialized epithelial cells that cover the outer surfaces of the glomerular capillaries. Their foot processes interdigitate and form filtration slits.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillary loops and provide structural support and phagocytic functions.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that filters blood and is involved in immune reactions.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: Dense connective tissue with smooth muscle cells.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule containing blood vessels.
  • White Pulp: Lymphatic tissue arranged around arterioles (central arteries). It's involved in immune responses.
  • Red Pulp: Consists of splenic cords (reticular connective tissue with many blood-filled sinuses). It filters the blood of antigens, microorganisms, and defective or worn-out red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, which are the two most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs. This resistance makes MDR-TB more difficult and longer to treat than drug-susceptible TB.

 

Isoniazid and rifampicin: These are the cornerstone drugs in the treatment of TB. MDR-TB's resistance to these drugs necessitates the use of second-line medications and a longer, more complex treatment regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and fluoroquinolone: While resistance to fluoroquinolones can occur, it characterizes pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) TB or extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB, not just MDR-TB.

 

Option B. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone resistance typically occurs in more advanced drug-resistant TB cases like pre-XDR and XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and kanamycin: This option refers to XDR-TB, which includes resistance to at least isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a second-line injectable drug such as kanamycin.

 

Note – Old definition of XDR - H and R resistance plus at least one fluoroquinolone resistance plus at least one second line injectable drug resistance like aminoglycosides (amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: Most common site of genital TB is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fallopian tube

 

Explanation:

 

Genital tuberculosis (TB) primarily affects the female reproductive system, with the fallopian tubes being the most common site of infection. Tuberculous salpingitis can lead to various complications, including:

 

  • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes.
  • Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube.
  • Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum.
  • Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.

 

These complications can significantly impact fertility, making infertility a common issue in women with genital TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Sites of Genital TB:

 

Option A. Cervix: Less commonly affected.

 

Option B. Endometrium: Can be involved, but not as frequently as the fallopian tubes.
 

Option D. Ovary: Also less commonly affected compared to the fallopian tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fallopian tube is the most common site of genital tuberculosis, leading to significant complications such as salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, and infertility.

questions.text: A patient has come to the clinic. Identify the movement being examined in the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction

 

The image provided depicts a clinical examination known as the Trendelenburg test. This test is used to assess the strength and function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. These muscles, innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, stabilize the pelvis during walking by keeping the pelvis level when one leg is lifted off the ground.

 

 

In a normal Trendelenburg test, when the patient stands on one leg, the gluteus medius and minimus on the standing leg contract to elevate the pelvis on the opposite side, maintaining balance. If the superior gluteal nerve is damaged or the gluteus medius and minimus muscles are weak or paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction: Adduction refers to the movement of a limb toward the midline of the body. This is not the movement being assessed in the Trendelenburg test.

 

Option B. Extension: Extension is the straightening movement that increases the angle between body parts, such as straightening the leg at the hip joint. The Trendelenburg test does not assess extension.

 

Option C. Flexion: Flexion refers to bending a joint, decreasing the angle between body parts. The Trendelenburg test is not assessing flexion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Trendelenburg test assesses the function of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are responsible for abduction of the thigh. A positive Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of these muscles, often due to damage to the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of prick injury came with the complaint: swelling of the foot with sinus tracts showing pus discharge, which showed white granules and gram-positive filamentous structures were noted on microscopy. What is the most likely causative organism associated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nocardia brasiliensis

 

This clinical scenario involving a farmer, a common occupation associated with exposure to organisms causing subcutaneous infections. The key clues here are:

 

  1. Prick injury: Suggests a subcutaneous mycosis or actinomycetoma.
  2. Swelling of the foot with sinus tracts, pus discharge, and white granules: These are characteristic features of mycetoma, also known as Madura foot.
  3. Gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy: This is a hallmark of actinomycetoma, specifically caused by bacterial agents like Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Mycetoma is classified into two types based on the causative organism: Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma

 

 

Given the presence of gram-positive filamentous structures and white granules, the most likely causative organism is Nocardia brasiliensis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Incorrect because it causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous mycosis, but does not produce granules or gram-positive filamentous structures.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect because, although it is gram-positive and can cause abscesses and sinus tracts, it does not form filamentous structures and is not typically associated with granules as seen in mycetoma.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because it is a fungus that can cause invasive infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but does not match the presentation described (i.e., white granules and gram-positive filaments).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma, or Madura foot, caused by Nocardia brasiliensis, presents with swelling, sinus tracts, white granules, and gram-positive filamentous structures on microscopy, distinguishing it from eumycetoma and other subcutaneous infections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male travels frequently and has food during his travels. He presents to PHC OPD with abdominal pain, fever for 4 days. He has bradycardia too. Test for confirmation of diagnosis: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood culture

 

The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of enteric fever (typhoid), characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. The appropriate diagnostic test depends on the stage of the illness:

 

Blood culture is the test of choice from the first week of illness onwards. It remains the most reliable test in the initial stages (within the first week of symptoms) to confirm typhoid fever. This test directly detects the presence of Salmonella bacteria in the blood, making it the most accurate diagnostic method during early illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella and is typically used from the second week of illness onwards. It is not the preferred test during the first week as antibodies may not yet be present in detectable quantities.

 

Option C. Stool culture: This is used from the third week of illness onwards and detects Salmonella in the gastrointestinal tract. It is not suitable for early diagnosis as it becomes positive later in the disease course.

 

Option D. Urine culture: This is used from the fourth week of illness onwards. It detects Salmonella excreted in the urine, but like stool culture, it is useful later in the course of the disease and not for initial diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For typhoid fever diagnosis in the first week of illness, blood culture is the most appropriate and reliable test.

 

Mnemonic – BASU

 

Blood culture – 1st week onwards

Antibody test (Widal) – 2nd week onwards

Stool culture – 3rd week onwards

Urine culture – 4th week onwards

questions.text: Which of the following factors will lead to an increase in the prevalence of a disease? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Longer duration of disease

 

  • Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have a specific disease at a given point in time. It is influenced by both the incidence (the rate of new cases) and the duration of the disease. 
  • When a disease has a longer duration, individuals remain affected by the disease for a longer period, thereby increasing the prevalence. This can occur in chronic conditions where treatment prolongs life without curing the disease or when there is a delay in effective treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immigration of healthy persons: Incorrect because the influx of healthy individuals into a population reduces the proportion of those with the disease, thereby decreasing prevalence.

 

Option B. Increased cure rate of disease: Incorrect as a higher cure rate means more people recover from the disease, reducing the number of existing cases and thus lowering prevalence.

 

Option D. Increased death rate in disease: Incorrect because a higher death rate reduces the number of people living with the disease, thereby decreasing the prevalence.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The prevalence of a disease increases with the longer duration of the disease, as more individuals remain affected over time.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

questions.text: A 6-week-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent projectile vomiting. USG of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 

The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is commonly seen in infants, particularly around 6 weeks of age, and is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to the thickening of the pyloric muscle, which leads to gastric outlet obstruction. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis, showing a thickened hypoechoic pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal, confirming the presence of CHPS. Key diagnostic measurements on ultrasound include pyloric muscle thickness greater than 4 mm and canal length greater than 16 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Typically presents with bilious vomiting and is associated with the “double bubble” sign on X-ray, not ultrasound. It does not present with projectile vomiting.

 

Option B. Jejunal atresia: Presents with bilious vomiting and is associated with a “triple bubble” sign on imaging studies, typically on X-ray. This condition does not match the clinical presentation or the ultrasound findings shown in the question.

 

Option D. Midgut volvulus: This condition presents with bilious vomiting and can show a corkscrew sign on contrast imaging studies due to the twisting of the bowel on its own axis. It is diagnosed using contrast imaging, not ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting in an infant around 6 weeks of age, and is best diagnosed with an ultrasound showing thickened pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal.

choices.text: Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler
Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A medical intern is observing an ultrasound for a patient with Rh isoimmunization. Which parameter is used to determine fetal anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raised PSV on MCA Doppler

 

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) is the gold standard non-invasive test for detecting fetal anemia. In fetal anemia, there is increased cardiac output and reduced blood viscosity, leading to faster blood flow. This results in increased PSV in the middle cerebral artery. A PSV value >1.5 MoM (Multiples of Median) for gestational age suggests significant fetal anemia and may indicate the need for further evaluation or intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced PSV on MCA Doppler: Incorrect because fetal anemia causes increased, not decreased, blood flow velocity in the MCA due to compensatory mechanisms.

 

Option C. Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: While umbilical artery Doppler is useful for assessing placental function and fetal well-being, it is not the primary tool for diagnosing fetal anemia. Changes in umbilical artery flow are more indicative of placental resistance.

 

Option D. Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: This finding is more associated with placental insufficiency and does not specifically indicate fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Increased Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler is the key non-invasive indicator of fetal anemia.

questions.text: A patient came following an RTA in the hospital. He is able to understand his friend’s talks. He is trying to speak (non-fluent aphasia) something to his friend. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Broca’s area

 

Explanation:

 

Broca’s area is responsible for speech production and language processing. It is located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) of the brain. Injury to Broca’s area leads to Broca’s aphasia, also known as non-fluent aphasia. Individuals with this condition can understand spoken language but have difficulty in speaking, writing, or forming words properly.

 

Broca’s area: Broca’s aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production. The patient may understand speech but will struggle to speak fluently, often speaking in short, broken sentences with considerable effort. This condition is also known as expressive aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s area: This area is involved in the comprehension of spoken language. Damage to Wernicke’s area results in Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent aphasia), where the patient can speak fluently but the speech is often nonsensical and lacks meaning.

 

Option B. Angular gyrus: This region is involved in various functions related to language, number processing, and spatial cognition but is not directly responsible for speech production or comprehension.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: This is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects Broca’s area and Wernicke’s area. Damage to this pathway can result in conduction aphasia, characterized by the ability to understand and produce speech but difficulty in repeating words or sentences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca’s area is involved in speech production. Damage to this area results in non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand speech but has difficulty speaking fluently.

questions.text: The LH surge is principally due to which of the following hormonal changes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sustained/marked rise in Estrogen

 

The LH surge is triggered by a sustained peak level of estrogen for 24-48 hours in the late follicular phase, which results in a positive feedback effect on the anterior pituitary. When estradiol reaches beyond the critical level of 200 pg/mL and is sustained for about 48 hours, it exerts this positive feedback action to LH. This sustained estrogen elevation is essential for triggering the preovulatory LH surge that initiates ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Falling FSH levels: This is incorrect because falling FSH levels do not trigger the LH surge. In fact, during the late follicular phase, there is actually a preovulatory FSH surge that accompanies the LH surge, though smaller in magnitude.

 

Option C. Rise in Progesterone: While there is a trace amount of 17-α-hydroxy progesterone formed prior to ovulation, it's not the primary trigger for LH surge. Rather, this small progesterone rise facilitates the positive feedback action of estrogen for the LH and FSH surge.

 

Option D. Rise in Prostaglandins: Prostaglandins play a role in the actual process of follicular rupture during ovulation, but are not responsible for triggering the LH surge. They are produced in response to the LH surge rather than being its cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midcycle LH surge is triggered by sustained high estradiol levels (>200 pg/mL for 48 hours) acting through positive feedback on the anterior pituitary - a critical mechanism that differs from estrogen's typical negative feedback effect seen during other phases of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A Mediterranean person receive primaquine. Which pathway is affected by G-6-PD enzyme deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMP pathway

 

This is the correct pathway affected by G6PD enzyme deficiency. G6PD is an enzyme crucial for the proper functioning of the HMP pathway. Deficiency in G6PD can lead to hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) in response to oxidative stress, as the HMP pathway is responsible for generating reducing equivalents (NADPH) necessary to protect cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the HMP pathway, not glycolysis. Glycolysis is a separate metabolic pathway involved in the breakdown of glucose for energy production.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is the metabolic pathway responsible for producing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, and it does not rely on the G6PD enzyme.

 

Option D. Krebs cycle: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle). The Krebs cycle is involved in the oxidative metabolism of acetyl-CoA, and G6PD deficiency primarily impacts the earlier steps of glucose metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD is the first and rate limiting enzyme of HMP pathway which is the major source of NADPH that is required for reduced glutathione generation and help reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals.

 

Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 182

questions.text: Which of the options is considered the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Designated Microscopy Centre 

 

  • Among the given options, the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure is the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC). This remains same for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.
  • The DMC is the first point of contact for patients seeking diagnosis and treatment for tuberculosis (TB) and is responsible for collecting sputum samples and conducting smear microscopy to detect the presence of TB bacteria. The DMCs are established at the periphery level of the healthcare system, such as at the level of Primary Health Centers or Community Health Centers, to ensure that TB diagnosis and treatment services are accessible to people in their own communities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: This option is higher up in the hierarchy than the DMC. It is responsible for the supervision and monitoring of TB control activities within the district, making it central but not the most peripheral.
 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory:  The IRL provides quality assurance for TB diagnosis and conducts drug susceptibility testing. It is a specialized facility that supports the network by confirming diagnoses and resistance patterns, placed higher in the organizational hierarchy than DMCs.
 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit:  While the Tuberculosis Unit is responsible for providing treatment and care to TB patients, it is not as peripheral as the DMC. The TU operates within a more integrated role in patient management and care continuum than the DMC, which is strictly focused on initial diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) remains a foundational component in the RNTCP for its role in accessible, community-level TB diagnosis and initial management. Its position as the most peripheral center in the hierarchy underscores its critical function in early TB detection and intervention.

choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: Cord clamping in the 3rd stage of labor is done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-3 mins

 

The correct answer is 1-3 mins. Delayed cord clamping is recommended by health guidelines to improve neonatal outcomes. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines delayed cord clamping as occurring between 30 to 60 seconds after birth, whereas American guidelines suggest waiting for 1 to 3 minutes. The common practice derived from both recommendations is to wait at least one minute.

 

Delayed Cord Clamping: This practice allows more blood to transfer from the placenta to the newborn, which can provide significant health benefits such as improved iron stores and reduced risk of anemia. Clamping the cord within 1-3 minutes after birth falls within the recommended window for delayed cord clamping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate: Immediate cord clamping, done within seconds after birth, is considered early cord clamping and does not provide the benefits associated with delayed cord clamping.

 

Option C. 5 mins: Waiting for 5 minutes is considered too long and is not a standard recommendation by any major health guidelines for delayed cord clamping.

 

Option D. Once cord pulsations stop: While waiting until cord pulsations stop can be an indicator, it is not the standard timing recommendation and may vary more widely than the 1-3 minute window suggested by guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed cord clamping is recommended to be performed 1-3 minutes after birth to optimize neonatal health outcomes.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

 

The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency. One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratosis pilaris rubra: Keratosis pilaris rubra is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, red bumps on the skin, often on the arms and thighs. It primarily affects the skin and does not directly relate to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Eczema: Eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. While eczema can affect the skin, it is not associated with night blindness, corneal drying, or Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that lead to dry, scaly, and thickened skin. It primarily affects the skin's texture and is not commonly associated with night blindness and corneal drying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.

 

Ref-Dinesh Puri 3rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: A patient who has a pet dog, came with a complaint of hypochondrial pain. The radiological imaging showed cyst within the liver. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The key points that indicate Echinococcus granulosus as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient has a pet dog, which is the definitive host for Echinococcus granulosus (also known as the dog tapeworm).
  2. The patient presented with hypochondrial pain, which could be caused by the formation of cyst in the liver.
  3. Radiological imaging revealed a cyst within the liver, which is characteristic of Echinococcus granulosus infection.

 

Echinococcus granulosus is a cestode (tapeworm) parasite that causes hydatid cyst disease, primarily affecting the liver and lungs. The life cycle involves dogs (or other canids like wolves and foxes) as the definitive hosts, where the adult tapeworm resides in the intestine. The eggs are passed in the feces of these definitive hosts and can contaminate food or water sources.

 

Humans become accidental intermediate hosts by ingesting these eggs. Once ingested, the eggs hatch in the human intestine, and the larvae migrate to various organs, most commonly the liver (70-80% of cases), where they develop into unilocular hydatid cyst.

 

 

 

Life cycle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This is a protozoan parasite that causes amebic liver abscesses, not multilocular cysts. It is not transmitted by dogs and does not form characteristic multilocular cysts.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Also known as the pork tapeworm, this organism can cause cysticercosis, where cysts form in muscle, brain, and other tissues, but it's not primarily known for liver cysts.

 

Option D. Diphyllobothrium latum: This is a fish tapeworm that primarily leads to vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia, not liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Echinococcus granulosus, also known as the dog tapeworm, can cause hydatid cyst disease in humans, with multilocular cysts commonly found in the liver. Owning a pet dog and ingesting food or water contaminated with dog feces containing the parasite's eggs are risk factors for acquiring this infection.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break.
