Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a parasitic worm that infects the bile ducts of the liver. Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a well-known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a type of cancer that occurs in the bile ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular cancer: This is commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B and C infections, cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure, not typically with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option C. Gastric cancer: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, dietary factors, and genetic predisposition, not with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option D. Urinary bladder cancer: Often linked to smoking, occupational exposures, and Schistosoma haematobium infection (another type of parasitic worm), not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Humans acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing the metacercariae (infective stage).

 

Chronic infection leads to:

 

  • Inflammation
  • Hyperplasia of the biliary epithelium
  • Fibrosis
  • Malignant transformation → Cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: A young male child presented with gum bleeding and bow legs. Which vitamin deficiency is commonly associated with the described features? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ascorbic acid

 

ASCORBIC ACID DEFICIENCY

 

  • Scurvy is a clinical syndrome resulting from vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency. 
  • Vitamin C is essential for the growth and repair of skin, cartilage, bone, and teeth.
  • Humans lack the active form of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase required for synthesizing ascorbic acid, making it essential to acquire vitamin C from dietary sources or supplements. 
  • The primary cause of vitamin C deficiency is due to inadequate nutritional intake.
  • Histopathology:
    • Microscopic examination of affected tissues reveals evidence of compromised collagen synthesis.
    • In the skin, there is evident dermal disruption and atrophy, reduced number of collagen fibers, and they appear fragmented.
    • The affected area displays signs of dilated hair follicles, fibrosis, follicular hyperkeratosis, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages. 
    • In the oral cavity, the gingival tissues exhibit hemorrhagic changes, characterized by capillary dilation and fibrin thrombi, subepithelial hemorrhages, and inflammatory infiltrates. 
    • Within the skeletal system, the osteoid matrix is thin and disrupted, accompanied by subperiosteal hemorrhages and indications of osteopenia.
  • Early oral signs visible in physical examination include gingivitis with bleeding, periodontal disease, loss of dentition.
  • About 80% of children with scurvy present with musculoskeletal signs and symptoms, including arthralgias, myalgias, hemarthroses, muscle hemorrhages, and subperiosteal hematomas.
  • Children might display a limp or resist bearing weight.
  • The knee joint is the most affected part of the body. 
  • Vitamin C deficiency can affect bone growth and development, leading to bone deformities like bow legs.
  • Another notable finding is the "scorbutic rosary," i.e., tender, angular, and sharp swellings at the costochondral junctions caused by weakened connective tissue.
  • Imaging studies may reveal the following:
    • Fractures and dislocations
    • Subperiosteal elevation
    • Alveolar bone resorption, osteopenia, or osteoporosis
    • Epiphyseal separation of the distal radius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tocopherol: Vitamin E deficiency is extremely rare in humans as it is unlikely caused by a diet consisting of low vitamin E. Patients presenting early may show hyporeflexia, decreased night vision, loss/decreased vibratory sense; however, they have normal cognition. A more moderate stage of this deficiency may show limb and truncal ataxia, profuse muscle weakness, and limited upward gaze. Late presentations may show cardiac arrhythmias and possible blindness with reduced cognition. Ataxia is the most common finding. Patients that have abetalipoproteinemia have eye problems, often including pigmented retinopathy and visual field issues.

 

Option C. Calciferol: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to osteomalacia and rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. The majority of patients with vitamin D deficiency are asymptomatic. However, even mild chronic vitamin D deficiency can lead to chronic hypocalcemia and hyperparathyroidism, which can contribute risk of osteoporosis, falls, and fractures, especially in older individuals. Patients with prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency can experience symptoms associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism, including bone pain, arthralgias, myalgias, fatigue, muscle twitching, and weakness. Fragility fractures may result from chronic vitamin D deficiency, leading to osteoporosis. In children, irritability, lethargy, developmental delay, bone changes, or fractures can be symptoms of vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option D. Biotin deficiency: Biotin deficiency is very rare in those who take in a normal balanced diet. Nominal biotin deficiency has been noted in pregnant and lactating women, but its clinical significance is unknown. Dermal abnormalities in biotin deficiency include alopecia and periorificial dermatitis. Patients may also develop conjunctivitis and skin infections. Neurological symptoms include hypotonia, seizures, ataxia, numbness and tingling of the extremities, mental retardation, and developmental delay in children. The patient may show depression, lethargy, and a history of hallucinations. Other neurological abnormalities include optic atrophy and sensorineural hearing loss if the condition is left untreated. Intestinal symptoms may also develop such as nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Other biotin deficiency presentations include ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and organic aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gum bleeding and bow legs are seen with Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid

 

  • The scenario described involves a young male patient who received a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure and subsequently became unresponsive with an unrecordable pulse.
  •  These are concerning signs of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), which can occur when local anesthetic drugs like bupivacaine enter the systemic circulation.
  • The best course of management for this patient is as follows:
  • This is the correct choice. Intralipid is a lipid emulsion used as the antidote for LAST.
  • It works by sequestering the local anesthetic drug in the lipid phase and reducing its toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  •  CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) should be initiated, and 20% intralipid should be administered intravenously to treat LAST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CPR with sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is not the first-line treatment for LAST. While it can be used to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias caused by local anesthetic toxicity, it does not directly counteract the toxic effects on the central nervous system and is not as effective as intralipid.

 

Option C. CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a medication used to increase cardiac output and blood pressure in some situations, but it is not the primary treatment for LAST.

 

Option D. CPR with calcium: Calcium does not reverse the toxic effects of local anesthetic systemic toxicity. Therefore, it is not the appropriate treatment for this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition.
  • Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV
